ray.rage.scene

Interface Tessellation

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Disposable, Managed<SceneManager>, Nameable, SceneObject, Visible
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericTessellation

    public interface Tessellation
extends SceneObject
    A tessellation is a textured plane that is primarily used to simulate terrain in a scene.

    The tessellation body holds the necessary functions required of a renderable object. The tessellation body holds quality data to define how many vertices are to be generated, but it does not hold any vertex information (because vertices are all generated in the tessellation shaders).

    Tessellations do not explicitly require a texture. Tessellations will use default.png by default.

    Tessellations do not explicitly require a height map. Tessellations will use default.png as a place-holder, and height calculations will be ignored (the height multiplying variable will be set to zero).

    Tessellations do not explicitly require a normal map. Tessellations will use default.png as a place-holder, and normals will be estimated in the default tessellation shaders. Generating normals without a normal map is sightly more computationally expensive than deriving them from a normal map.

    If a tessellation is queried for a height value, but the X-Z coordinate do not fall within the bounds of the plane, the tessellation will normalize the given X-Z coordinates to the closest point on the edge of the plane.

    It is advised to avoid pitching or rolling the scene node the tessellation is attached to. Doing so will break any height queries made to the tessellation. Performing a yaw about the global Y-Axis is acceptable, because tessellations assume that the Y-Axis will be used to signify "up" and "down".

    It is advised to avoid Scaling the scene node in a negative direction on the X, Y, or Z axes. Tessellations do account for scaling when height queries are made, but caution should be taken when Scaling the X and Z axes negatively. Clients must be aware that the X and Z axes must both be positive or both be negative. If only one or the other is negative, and the other is positive, the tessellation will not render as intended.

    Author:
    Kevin S. Cheong

      • setHeightMap

        void setHeightMap(Engine eng,
                  java.lang.String texPath)
        Sets the specified texture onto the tessellation as a height map.

        The red pixel data values are used to determine height.

        modifying the tessellation multiplier variable may be used to adjust the extremeties of the heights.

        Parameters:
        eng - The engine.
        texPath - The filename of the texture (e.g. "default.png").
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If any of the arguments is null.

      • setMultiplier

        void setMultiplier(float amount)
        Multiplies the red values in the pixel data of provided height maps.

        The multiplier is automatically set to zero when the tessellation is first created, or if the client calls removeHeightMap.

        The multiplier is automatically set to one when the client calls setTexture.

        Parameters:
        amount - The amount to multiply reds. Negative values are permitted.

      • setSubdivisions

        void setSubdivisions(float amount)
        Sets the amount of subdivisions during the tessellation process done in the tessellation shaders. It is set to zero by default.

        Subdivisions are used to perform Level-of-Detail (LOD) operations in an attempt to make tessellations less expensive to perform and maintain. Making the subdivisions higher improves performance in theory, but may cause unwanted visible "cracks" in the tessellated plane.

        Parameters:
        amount - The amount to subdivide tessellated vertices by.

      • setQuality

        void setQuality(int amount)
        Sets the amount of vertices created during the tessellation process done in the tessellation shaders. It is set to a level of seven by default.

        Quality levels are used to perform geometry (primitive) generating operations in an attempt to make tessellations less expensive to perform and maintain. Making the quality lower improves performance in theory, but may cause inaccurate visual height representations and poor height query results.

        The minimum quality level is 5 (32x32 vertex patches). There is no maximum quality, but it is recommended to not use anything higher than a quality level of 10 (1024x1024 vertex patches). If the client attempts to assign a quality level of 4 or lower, it will be set to 5.

        Parameters:
        amount - The level of quality to set.

      • getTexture

        Texture getTexture()
        Gets the texture currently being used on the tessellation. If a texture has not been supplied, it will return the default texture default.png.

      • removeHeightMap

        void removeHeightMap(Engine eng)
        Removes the texture currently being used on the tessellation as a height map, and replaces it with the default texture default.png.

        When this is called, the tessellation's height multiplier is automatically set to zero.

        Parameters:
        eng - The engine.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If any of the arguments is null.

      • removeNormalMap

        void removeNormalMap(Engine eng)
        Removes the texture currently being used on the tessellation as a normal map, and replaces it with the default texture default.png.

        When this is called, the tessellation will switch to estimating normals in the tessellation shaders.

        Parameters:
        eng - The engine.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If any of the arguments is null.

      • getMultiplier

        float getMultiplier()
        Returns the current multiplier. The multiplier adjusts the height map values.

        If the tessellation is first created, or has its height map removed, the multiplier will automatically be set to zero.

        If the tessellation is provided a new height map, the multiplier will automatically be set to one.

        Returns:
        multiplier

      • getSubdivisions

        float getSubdivisions()
        Returns the current subdivision amount. Subdivisions adjust the spacing of vertices generated in the tessellation shaders, causing vertices to be less densely generated the farther away they are from the client's . Level-of-Detail (LOD) operations require subdivisons to be some positive number.

        If the tessellation is first created, the subdivisions are set to zero, essentially disabling LOD.

        Having subdivisions less than zero are permitted, but vertices near the client's will not be generated; may cause unwanted visual results.

        Having subdivisions set to zero is essentially disabling LOD.

        Having a positive value in subdivisions may improve performance, but could also cause unwanted visual artifacts (such as cracks appearing on the plane).

        Returns:
        subdivisions

      • getWorldHeight

        float getWorldHeight(float globalX,
                     float globalZ)
        Returns the height of a particular point on the tessellation in world space.

        Because tessellations are attached to just like other objects, they can be transformed arbitrarily within certain limitations. This method will convert global X and Z coordinates into local X and Z coordinates relative to the tessellation.

        It is permitted to supply coordinates that do not land on the tessellated plane. If clients supply a coordinates that do not intersect the plane on the global Y-Axis, the closest points on the tessellation will be used.

        The height is determined by identifying the pixel (from the height map) associated with the supplied coordinates. It is then averaged (with weights) with the 3 closest pixels.

        For some examples: If the supplied coordinates happen to perfectly land in the center of a pixel from the height map, 100% of the returned amount will come from that one pixel. If the supplied coordinate lands perfectly between 2 pixels, each pixel will contribute 50% of its height. If the supplied coordinates land mostly on one pixel, but is not perfectly centered, it will take weighted averages from the closest lateral pixel, the closest longitudinal pixel, and the closest diagonal pixel. If a neighboring pixel does not exist (such as on the edges of a tessellated plane), the closest pixel on the edge is used.

        It is possible for 1 pixel to be used for several points on the tessellation.

        Clients should take care to avoid making height queries along the edges of a tessellated plane.

        Clients should take care to avoid pitching or rolling the the tessellation is attached to, as this will disturb the accuracy of the (X, Z) coordinate conversions. Yawing is allowed, and negative scaling is allowed, but clients should keep in mind that if any negative scaling is done on the X-Axis, it must also be done on the Z-Axis (and vice versa). Negative scaling on the Y-Axis can be done independently). Any arbitrary translation is permitted.

        The amount returned is calculated as follows:
        The weighted averages of the red values from the height map...
        ...multiplied by the multiplier...
        ...multiplied by the tessellation's scaling in the Y direction...
        ...with all of the above added to the tessellation's global Y position.

        Parameters:
        globalX - Any arbitrary X coordinate that exists in the game's world, preferably one located near the tessellation.
        globalZ - Any arbitrary Z coordinate that exists in the game's world, preferably one located near the tessellation.
        Returns:
        height The Y coordinate in global space.

      • getAverageHeight

        float getAverageHeight(float xPercent,
                       float zPercent)
        Returns the height of a particular point on the tessellation.

        If the bottom left of a tessellation is considered to be (0, 0) and the top right is considered to be (1, 1), (X, Z) coordinates can be supplied to query a particular point on the tessellated terrain to determine the Y coordinate.

        It is permitted to supply coordinates that do not land on the tessellated plane. If clients supply a coordinate value less than zero, it will be set to zero. Likewise, if a supplied coordinate is greater than one, it will be set to one.

        The height is determined by identifying the pixel (from the height map) associated with the supplied coordinates. It is then averaged (with weights) with the 3 closest pixels.

        For some examples: If the supplied coordinates happen to perfectly land in the center of a pixel from the height map, 100% of the returned amount will come from that one pixel. If the supplied coordinate lands perfectly between 2 pixels, each pixel will contribute 50% of its height. If the supplied coordinates land mostly on one pixel, but is not perfectly centered, it will take weighted averages from the closest lateral pixel, the closest longitudinal pixel, and the closest diagonal pixel. If a neighboring pixel does not exist (such as on the edges of a tessellated plane), the closest pixel on the edge is used.

        It is possible for 1 pixel to be used for several points on the tessellation.

        Clients should take care to avoid making height queries along the edges of a tessellated plane.

        The amount returned is calculated as follows:
        The weighted averages of the red values from the height map...
        ...multiplied by the multiplier...
        ...multiplied by the tessellation's scaling in the Y direction...
        ...with all of the above added to the tessellation's global Y position.

        Parameters:
        xPercent - A value between 0.0 to 1.0, 0.5 being the center of the tessellation along the X-Axis.
        zPercent - A value between 0.0 to 1.0, 0.5 being the center of the tessellation along the Z-Axis.
        Returns:
        height The Y coordinate in the tessellation's local space.

      • getQualityLevel

        int getQualityLevel()
        Returns the current quality level. The quality adjusts how many vertices are generated per patch during tessellation in the default tessellation shaders.

        Upon creation of a tessellation, the quality is set to seven by default. The quality level must be a minimum of five. No maximum is enforced, though it is advised to use a value of ten or less.

        Higher quality levels typically improve the accuracy of height queries, but may impact performance.

        Returns:
        quality level

      • getQualityTotal

        int getQualityTotal()
        Returns the amount: 2^(quality level). The quality total squared is the amount of primitives generated during tessellation in the default tessellation shaders.

        Upon creation of a tessellation, the quality is set to seven by default (creating a quality total of 128). The quality level must be a minimum of five (a total of 32). No maximum is enforced, though it is advised to use a value of ten or less (2^10 is 1024).

        Higher quality levels typically improve the accuracy of height queries, but may impact performance.

        This call is mostly needed by GL4RenderSystem and GlslTessProgram.

        Returns:
        quality total
